prompt: produce a table of the most common topics and their frequency

analysis.executive_summary: Analysis of the two provided news excerpts (AustralianNewsHeadlines.txt and Bbc.txt) shows that the most frequently mentioned topic is the United States trade tariff decision involving President Donald Trump, appearing in both sources (2 mentions). All other identified topics (royalty/legal issues, infectious disease alert, business leadership death, sports/entertainment decisions) appear only once.
key_trends: US trade policy and Supreme Court ruling on Trump tariffs dominates coverage across sources.
Royal family legal matters (Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor arrest) receive attention in Australian headlines.
Public health alert regarding a highly‑infectious disease outbreak is highlighted.
Notable business figure death (ASOS co‑founder) reported.
Sports and entertainment decisions (IOC ruling, Jake Paul’s girlfriend) are noted.
analysis.delta_start_to_end: Within the single day of 2026‑02‑20, the tariff story persists across both Australian and UK news outlets, indicating a consistent, cross‑regional focus on US trade policy; no new topics emerge over the timeframe.
supporting_evidence: AustralianNewsHeadlines.txt: "Donald Trump’s controversial global tariffs on foreign imports have been struck down by the US Supreme Court in a landmark decision."
Bbc.txt: "Tariffs ruling is major blow to Trump's second-term agenda" and "The Trump administration had plenty of time to prepare for Friday's decision..."
AustralianNewsHeadlines.txt: "details of how Fergie is handling Andrew’s arrest have emerged" (royalty/legal issue).
AustralianNewsHeadlines.txt: "An outbreak of a highly‑infectious disease has prompted authorities to issue a new alert" (health alert).
AustralianNewsHeadlines.txt: "One of the co‑founders of online fashion retailer ASOS has tragically died in Thailand" (business death).
AustralianNewsHeadlines.txt: "The IOC has made its decision regarding Jake Paul’s girlfriend’s $1.4m move" (sports/entertainment).
caveats: The dataset consists of only two excerpts, limiting the ability to generalize frequency counts.
Topic identification is based on brief summaries; deeper article content may reveal additional nuances.
Frequency reflects mentions in the provided excerpts, not overall news volume for the day.
